query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
1 Mentre che li occhi per la fronda verde 2 ficcava ïo sì come far suole 3 chi dietro a li uccellin sua vita perde,
4 lo più che padre mi dicea: «Figliuole, 5 vienne oramai, ché ’l tempo che n’è imposto 6 più utilmente compartir si vuole».
query.result:
**English:**
1 While my eyes were fixed on the green leaves, 2 as one who loses his life following the birds, 3 my father said to me: "My son, 4 come now, for the time that is allotted to us 5 should be spent more usefully."
**Old English:**
1 Þa ic ða mid ðam eagum on ða grene leafe 2 fæste behealdende wæs swa swa se ðe his lif 3 æfter fuglum forleosan sceal,
4 ða me min fæder cwæð: "Min sunu, 5 cym nu hraðe, forðam ðe se tima þe us geseald is 6 nytlicor gedælan mæg."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
7 Io volsi ’l viso, e ’l passo non men tosto, 8 appresso i savi, che parlavan sìe, 9 che l’andar mi facean di nullo costo.
query.result:
**English:**
7 I turned my face, and my steps no less swiftly, 8 after the wise men, who spoke so, 9 that they made my going seem of no cost.
**Old English:**
7 Ic me wende ða, and ðone weg ne lætte, 8 æfter ðam wisan ðe ða word spræcon, 9 ða ðe me ðone gang ðurh ða graman worhton.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
10 Ed ecco piangere e cantar s’udìe 11 ‘Labïa mëa, Domine’ per modo 12 tal, che diletto e doglia parturìe.
query.result:
**English:**
10 And behold, weeping and singing were heard, 11 “Labia mea, Domine” in such a way 12 that it produced delight and sorrow.
**Old English:**
10 And ða ic gehyrde wepan and song 11 “Labia mea, Domine” on ðone wisan 12 ðæt hit geworhte wyn and wop.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
13 «O dolce padre, che è quel ch’i’ odo?», 14 comincia’ io; ed elli: «Ombre che vanno 15 forse di lor dover solvendo il nodo».
query.result:
**English:**
13 "O sweet father, what is that which I hear?" 14 I began; and he: "Shades that go, 15 perhaps discharging the knot of their duty."
**Old English:**
13 "Eala ðu leofa fæder, hwæt is ðæt ðe ic gehyre?" 14 ic ongann; and he cwæð: "Hit sind ða sawle ðe farað, 15 ðurh ðone cnot hyra ðeowdomes ðone hi gedydon sceolon."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
16 Sì come i peregrin pensosi fanno, 17 giugnendo per cammin gente non nota, 18 che si volgono ad essa e non restanno,
19 così di retro a noi, più tosto mota, 20 venendo e trapassando ci ammirava 21 d’anime turba tacita e devota.
query.result:
**English:**
16 Just as thoughtful pilgrims do, 17 arriving on an unfamiliar road, 18 who turn to look at it and do not stop,
19 so behind us, moving somewhat faster, 20 came and passed us a crowd of silent and devout souls, 21 wondering who we were.
**Old English:**
16 Swa swa ða wærfæstan wilgeocas doð, 17 cumande on uncuðne weg, 18 ðe to ðam siðe oft gewendan, and ne geswican,
19 swa æfter us, sumraðe hraðor, 20 com and forð gewat ðreat sawla ðigna 21 wundrigende hwa we wæron.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
22 Ne li occhi era ciascuna oscura e cava, 23 palida ne la faccia, e tanto scema 24 che da l’ossa la pelle s’informava.
query.result:
**English:**
22 In her eyes each one was dark and hollow, 23 pale in the face, and so wasted away 24 that the skin clung to her bones.
**Old English:**
22 On hire eagum wæs ælc ðiostor and hol, 23 bleoh on andwlitan, and swa swiðe hreoh, 24 ðæt ðæt fel to ðæm banum fæst wæs.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
25 Non credo che così a buccia strema 26 Erisittone fosse fatto secco, 27 per digiunar, quando più n’ebbe tema.
query.result:
**English:**
25 I do not believe that Erysichthon was made so thin and dry, 26 through fasting, when he had the greatest fear of it.
**Old English:**
25 Ne wene ic ðæt swa ðynne and swa dreorigne 26 Erysichthon æfre wurde, 27 ðurh fæstenne, ða he ðæs mæste ege hæfde.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
28 Io dicea fra me stesso pensando: ‘Ecco 29 la gente che perdé Ierusalemme, 30 quando Maria nel figlio diè di becco!’
31 Parean l’occhiaie anella sanza gemme: 32 chi nel viso de li uomini legge ‘omo’ 33 ben avria quivi conosciuta l’emme.
query.result:
**English:**
28 I said to myself, thinking: ‘Behold 29 the people who lost Jerusalem, 30 when Mary gave her Son a kiss!’
31 Their eye sockets seemed like rings without gems: 32 he who reads ‘man’ in the face of men 33 would have recognized the letter ‘M’ here.
**Old English:**
28 Ic cwæð to me sylfum ðencende: ‘Efne 29 ðæt folc ðe forleas Ierusalem, 30 ða ða Maria hire sunu beceorfode!’
31 Hiora eagþyrl synt geliсe hringum butan gimmum: 32 se ðe on ðæra manna ansyne ræt ‘man’ 33 he hæfde her gecnawen ðone staef ‘M’.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
34 Chi crederebbe che l’odor d’un pomo 35 sì governasse, generando brama, 36 e quel d’un’acqua, non sappiendo como?
37 Già era in ammirar che sì li affama, 38 per la cagione ancor non manifesta 39 di lor magrezza e di lor trista squama,
40 ed ecco del profondo de la testa 41 volse a me li occhi un’ombra e guardò fiso; 42 poi gridò forte: «Qual grazia m’è questa?».
query.result:
**English:**
34 Who would believe that the scent of an apple 35 could govern so, generating desire, 36 and that of water, not knowing how?
37 I was already marveling at what so famished them, 38 for the cause of their thinness and their sad scales 39 was not yet manifest,
40 and behold, from the depths of his head 41 a shade turned his eyes to me and stared intently; 42 then he cried out loudly: "What grace is this for me?"
**Old English:**
34 Hwa mæg wenan ðæt æpples geleaf 35 swa stieran mihte, lust aweccan, 36 and wætres drync, ne ðæt ne wisse?
37 Ic wæs ða wundrigende ðæt swa hyne gegremede, 38 ðurh ðæs ðinges ðearfe ðe ða gyt dygol wæs, 39 heora mægðe and heora morðre scealwe,
40 and ða sona of ðæs heafdes grunde 41 wende ða his eagan to me weard and wrathlíc clypode; 42 ða he hlud gehloh: "Hwilc is ðeos milts?"

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
43 Mai non l’avrei riconosciuto al viso; 44 ma ne la voce sua mi fu palese 45 ciò che l’aspetto in sé avea conquiso.
query.result:
**English:**
43 I would never have recognized him by his face; 44 but in his voice it was revealed to me 45 what his appearance had conquered within itself.
**Old English:**
43 Nefre ic hine on ðam ansyne oncneow; 44 ac on ðære stefne me wearð stearc 45 ðæt ðæt hiw ðærbinnan hæfde oferwunnen.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
46 Questa favilla tutta mi raccese 47 mia conoscenza a la cangiata labbia, 48 e ravvisai la faccia di Forese.
query.result:
**English:**
46 This spark rekindled all of me, 47 my knowledge at the changed appearance, 48 and I recognized the face of Forese.
**Old English:**
46 Þeos fawela eallunga me onbryrde 47 min geþanc on ða awendede hiw, 48 and ic oncneow ðæs muð Forese.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
55 «La faccia tua, ch’io lagrimai già morta, 56 mi dà di pianger mo non minor doglia», 57 rispuos’ io lui, «veggendola sì torta.
query.result:
**English:**
55 "Your face, which I saw dead with tears, 56 gives me no less grief to weep for now," 57 I answered him, "seeing it so contorted.
**Old English:**
55 "Ðin neb, ðe ic wepende ða dead, 56 me gifeð nu ðe mare reowðe," 57 ic him andswarode, "ðus hit to wætrene.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
58 Però mi dì, per Dio, che sì vi sfoglia; 59 non mi far dir mentr’ io mi maraviglio, 60 ché mal può dir chi è pien d’altra voglia».
query.result:
**English:**
58 Therefore tell me, for God's sake, who strips you so; 59 do not make me speak while I am marveling, 60 for he who is full of other desire can speak poorly.
**Old English:**
58 Forðæm sege me, ðurh God, hwa iow ðus blaceð; 59 ne læt ðu me sprecan ða hwile ðe ic wundrige, 60 forðæm yfle mæg sprecan se ðe is ðæs oðres gitsful.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
61 Ed elli a me: «De l’etterno consiglio 62 cade vertù ne l’acqua e ne la pianta 63 rimasa dietro ond’ io sì m’assottiglio.
query.result:
**English:**
61 And he to me: "From the eternal counsel 62 virtue falls into the water and into the plant 63 left behind, from which I so diminish myself.
**Old English:**
61 And he to me: "From ðæm ælmihtigan ræde 62 fealleð miht on wæter and on wudu 63 ða ðe ðær æfter wæs ðonne ic me swiðe amæte.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
64 Tutta esta gente che piangendo canta 65 per seguitar la gola oltra misura, 66 in fame e ’n sete qui si rifà santa.
query.result:
**English:**
64 All these people who weep as they sing, 65 for following gluttony beyond measure, 66 here make themselves holy in hunger and thirst.
**Old English:**
64 Ealle ða leode ðe wepende singað 65 forðæm ðe ða gifernesse ða ofermæðe folgiað, 66 on hungre and on þurste ðær ða halgan beoð.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
67 Di bere e di mangiar n’accende cura 68 l’odor ch’esce del pomo e de lo sprazzo 69 che si distende su per sua verdura.
query.result:
**English:**
67 He does not care to eat or drink, 68 the smell that comes from the fruit and from the spray 69 that spreads over its verdure.
**Old English:**
67 Ne bið him ænig caru 68 ðæs wæstmes geogoðu ne ðæs wæteres drync, 69 ac ðæs wudu smell him bið swetra.
Please note that the Old English translation is a poetic rendering, rather than a literal translation, in order to capture the beauty and imagery of the original Italian.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
70 E non pur una volta, questo spazzo 71 girando, si rinfresca nostra pena: 72 io dico pena, e dovria dir sollazzo,
73 ché quella voglia a li alberi ci mena 74 che menò Cristo lieto a dire ‘Elì’, 75 quando ne liberò con la sua vena».
query.result:
**English:**
70 And not just once, this space 71 revolving, refreshes our pain: 72 I say pain, and I should say solace,
73 for that desire leads us to the trees 74 that led Christ, joyful, to say ‘Eli’, 75 when he freed us with his blood.
**Old English:**
70 And nis ðæt an ðæt ðeos spel 71 hweorfað, ðe ure sar gewægað: 72 ic secge sar, and sceolde secgan lisse,
73 forðæm ðe ðeos wilnung us lædeð to ðæm treowum 74 ðe læddon Crist bliðe ðæt he cwæð ‘Eli’, 75 ða he us alysde ðurh his agen blod.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
76 E io a lui: «Forese, da quel dì 77 nel qual mutasti mondo a miglior vita, 78 cinqu’ anni non son vòlti infino a qui.
query.result:
**English:**
76 And I to him: "Forese, since that day 77 when you changed worlds to a better life, 78 five years have not yet passed until now.
**Old English:**
76 And ic to him: "Forese, fram ðam dæge 77 ðe ðu forlete woruld to betere life, 78 fif gear sindon agane oð ðis."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
79 Se prima fu la possa in te finita 80 di peccar più, che sovvenisse l’ora 81 del buon dolor ch’a Dio ne rimarita,
82 come se’ tu qua sù venuto ancora? 83 Io ti credea trovar là giù di sotto, 84 dove tempo per tempo si ristora».
query.result:
**English:**
79 If the power to sin was ended in you 80 before the hour of good sorrow came 81 that remarries us to God,
82 how is it that you have come up here? 83 I thought to find you down there below, 84 where time is restored, moment by moment.
**Old English:**
79 Gif ðin miht wæs ær geendod 80 to syngienne, ærðon ðæt tid come 81 ðæs godan hryws ðe us to Gode gegearwoð,
82 hu eart ðu ða hider cumen? 83 Ic wende ðe findan nyðer, 84 ðær tid be tide bið geedniwod.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
85 Ond’ elli a me: «Sì tosto m’ha condotto 86 a ber lo dolce assenzo d’i martìri 87 la Nella mia con suo pianger dirotto.
query.result:
**English:**
85 And she said to me: "So quickly has Nella, 86 with her bitter weeping, led me 87 to bear the sweet wormwood of martyrdom.
**Old English:**
85 Ond heo ða to me cwæð: "Swa hrædlice mæ ðider gelædde 86 ðæt bitere reowð ðære martyra 87 Nella mid hire tearum ðe heo tearymlice weop."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
88 Con suoi prieghi devoti e con sospiri 89 tratto m’ha de la costa ove s’aspetta, 90 e liberato m’ha de li altri giri.
query.result:
**English:**
88 With her devout prayers and with sighs 89 she has drawn me from the shore where one waits, 90 and has freed me from the other circles.
**Old English:**
88 Mid hire halgum bene and mid hire wopum 89 heo me lædde of ðære sæcce ðær mon sceal bidan, 90 and heo me nerede of ðam oprum hellegatum.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
97 O dolce frate, che vuo’ tu ch’io dica? 98 Tempo futuro m’è già nel cospetto, 99 cui non sarà quest’ ora molto antica,
100 nel qual sarà in pergamo interdetto 101 a le sfacciate donne fiorentine 102 l’andar mostrando con le poppe il petto.
query.result:
**English:**
97 O sweet brother, what do you want me to say? 98 The future is already before my eyes, 99 and this present hour will soon seem ancient to it,
100 in which it will be forbidden from the pulpit 101 for the shameless women of Florence 102 to go about showing their breasts.
**Old English:**
97 Eala, leofa broðor, hwæt wille ðu ðæt ic secge? 98 To-weard tima is me nu on gesyhðe, 99 ðam ne bið ðeos tid miclum giungra,
100 on ðam bið on preostsetle forboden 101 ðam scyldigum wifmannum on Florentia 102 ðæt hie faran and ða breost sýnigen.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
103 Quai barbare fuor mai, quai saracine, 104 cui bisognasse, per farle ir coperte, 105 o spiritali o altre discipline?
106 Ma se le svergognate fosser certe 107 di quel che ’l ciel veloce loro ammanna, 108 già per urlare avrian le bocche aperte;
109 ché, se l’antiveder qui non m’inganna, 110 prima fien triste che le guance impeli 111 colui che mo si consola con nanna.
query.result:
**English:**
103 What barbarians or Saracens 104 ever needed, to make them go covered, 105 either spiritual or other disciplines?
106 But if the shameless women were certain 107 of what the swift heavens are preparing for them, 108 they would already have their mouths open to scream;
109 for, if my foresight does not deceive me here, 110 they will be sad before the one who now consoles himself with lullabies 111 has hair on his cheeks.
**Old English:**
103 Hwilce wæron æfre ða wælhreowan, ða Sarraceniscan, 104 ðe him beðurfon, ðæt hi wæron bewrigen, 105 oððe gastlice oððe oðre lare?
106 Ac gif ða scamlestan wæron gewisse 107 ðæs ðe ðæt hrædlice heofon him gearcað, 108 hi hæfdon nu ða muðas unlocen to hrymanne;
109 forðæm, gif min foresewennys her ne leogað, 110 hi beoð ær unrote ðonne ðæt gewædo 111 ðone þe nu mid nænigum ðingum ne bið geðreafod.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
112 Deh, frate, or fa che più non mi ti celi! 113 vedi che non pur io, ma questa gente 114 tutta rimira là dove ’l sol veli».
query.result:
**English:**
112 Oh, brother, now do not hide it from me any longer! 113 See that not only I, but all these people 114 are looking over there where the sun sets.
**Old English:**
112 Eala, broðor, nu ðu me ne cel nænig þing! 113 geseoh ðæt nis ðeah ðu ana, ac ðeos mænigeo 114 eall bið behealdend ðær ðe sunne westeð.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
115 Per ch’io a lui: «Se tu riduci a mente 116 qual fosti meco, e qual io teco fui, 117 ancor fia grave il memorar presente.
query.result:
**English:**
115 Wherefore I said to him: "If you recall 116 what I was with you, and what you were with me, 117 the present memory will still be grievous."
**Old English:**
115 Forðæm ic him ða cwæð: "Gif ðu ðone gemynd 116 hwæt ic wæs mid ðe, and hwæt ðu mid me wære, 117 ðonne bið ðeos andware ðe ðeah sarlic."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
118 Di quella vita mi volse costui 119 che mi va innanzi, l’altr’ ier, quando tonda 120 vi si mostrò la suora di colui»,
121 e ’l sol mostrai; «costui per la profonda 122 notte menato m’ha d’i veri morti 123 con questa vera carne che ’l seconda.
query.result:
**English:**
118 From that life he turned me away, 119 who goes before me, the other day, when round 120 the sister of him showed herself to you,
121 and I showed the sun; "this one through the deep 122 night has led me away from the true dead 123 with this real flesh that follows him.
**Old English:**
118 Of ðam life he me gewende, 119 se ðe me gæð beforan, ða ða ðu ðone hring 120 ðære sweostor his ðe æteowdest,
121 and ðone sunnan ic ðe æteowde; "ðes ðurh ða deopan 122 niht me lædde fram ðam soðan deade 123 mid ðysum soðan flæsce ðe him fylgð."

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
124 Indi m’han tratto sù li suoi conforti, 125 salendo e rigirando la montagna 126 che drizza voi che ’l mondo fece torti.
query.result:
**English:**
124 Then his encouragements lifted me up, 125 as I climbed and circled the mountain 126 that sets you straight, you whom the world made crooked.
**Old English:**
124 Þa me his frofor eft ongean gewende, 125 stigende and stigende ðone munt upp, 126 se ðe eow drihten dyde ðone deofol gedwylde.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
127 Tanto dice di farmi sua compagna 128 che io sarò là dove fia Beatrice; 129 quivi convien che sanza lui rimagna.
query.result:
**English:**
127 He says so much about making me his companion 128 that I will be where Beatrice is; 129 there it is necessary that I remain without him.
**Old English:**
127 Swa micelhe sædeð ðæt he wille ðæt ic beo his ifeola, 128 ðæt ic beo ðær ðær Beatrice is; 129 ðær ic sceal wunian butan him.

query.prompt:
Please translate each line literally into English and Old English.
130 Virgilio è questi che così mi dice», 131 e addita’lo; «e quest’ altro è quell’ ombra 132 per cuï scosse dianzi ogne pendice
133 lo vostro regno, che da sé lo sgombra».
query.result:
**English:**
130 Virgil is this who thus speaks to me," 131 and points him out; "and this other is that shade 132 for whom just now every slope trembled,
133 your kingdom, which expels him from itself."
**Old English:**
130 Virgilius is ðeos ðe ðus mecwæð, 131 and ðone tæcð; "and ðeos oðer is se sceaða 132 ðurh ðone ær ðis eall land bifode,
133 eower rice, ðe hine sylfne ðanon adræfð."
